Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2007 09:17PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: emg....that was funny about the keeping the lids loose. I wish I would have had that tip!! I am sooooo sorry you were in the hospital for so long. I didn't have that ...thank God. Eileen, everyone is different. I had my bi-mast on 3/21 first thing in the morning. I was home by 11:00 am the next morning. Everything was numb. I was very stiff and uncomfortable but really no pain. I can't really answer the question about work because....I closed my business after my diagnosis. I think the stress I was under helped my cancer rear it's ugly head. But, I was up walking around the next day. I did sleep alot for the first few days though. Getting up out of bed was bad. Hope you have strong stomach muscles!! So emg is right about propping yourself up. To this day, I sleep on my back because of my expanders. Can't wait to sleep on my stomach. Wait....can you do that with implants??????? Anyway, my best advise is to go and buy the softest.........button up jammie or other tops you can find. My sister bought me a pair and I swear...I laid in bed while she washed it for me. It was the only thing I felt comfortable in. I drove myself to church after a week and a half. Don't forget to stretch. Stretch and hold. That really, really helps. Good luck girl. Traci oh yea....your question about washing your hair. Hopefully, you'll be like me and be able to lean over the kitchen sink while someone washes your hair in no time.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 05:51PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: Diane....I'm so sorry to hear this...... I have an idea though.....ok...you said you don't have "much" help...but, I'm sure you can find a neighbor or one of your kids friends to get the boys out of the house for few hours. Right? Plan a early dinner to be delivered at a specific time, doesn't have to be anything fancy.....(even places that don't deliver will, if you ask them at a non-peak time). And before that, have two massage therapists come over and give you guys duo massages!! You can do this for as little as $100 (each of course...) here. They will come to your house  with bed and all.....but...before that, bath maybe......candles and soft music! So you have a nice bath, massage and then a relaxing dinner that cleans up in as much time as it takes you to throw it in the garbage! I've heard you talk about him.....I feel in my heart, you guys will be o.k. girl. Just another bump in the road. In my humble, opinion. Hugs, Traci

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2007 07:32PM - edited Oct 3, 2007 07:32PM by Traci-----TripNeg Hey Wispers, Good news....you can handle chemo many, many times! Bad news....I'm sorry you are facing it again. So Sorry. I'm right with you....I never.................want to do chemo again. Fact is, there are women on this site that have done practically non-stop chemo for YEARS.....trying to find one that works. I mean....literally...a break of several weeks here and there but other than that....chemo...every week, two weeks, three weeks, whatever. Again, I don't mean to sound negative. My point is.....they are still living (and, having fun) and fighting......if you have to do chemo again...yes, your body can handle it and, it will hopefully kick some cancer butt...just like your last one did. NED (No Evidence of Disease) for six years!!! You can do that again! You might want to check out the recurrance thread. Almost everybody there has had a recurrance of cancer and subsequently, chemo....again. And, you'll find that everybody....who isn't having a bad day.....(which we all have) has a super positive attitude! That thread has comforted me in more ways than words can describe. Good luck girl. Know we are here for you and know that you can....do it again. As some say on here...I am sending you great, big, giant, gentle cyber hugs. Traci

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2008 03:04PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: When I was bald (about 2 inches of hair ago) I refused to let anyone see me except the lady who helped me try on wigs. I HATED it. I literally slept with a scarf on my head just in case somebody came into my bedroom univited to see if I was puking from chemo. My mom didn't see me bald, my siblings didn't, my best friend in the whole wide world didn't, my roommate didn't. NOBODY besides that wig lady did. When I had my implant surgery, I told the nurse and doctor, "this bandana better still be on my head when I wake up". I meant it and, it was. It was as far from a laughing matter as anything I have ever experienced in my life. Call it vanity, call it lack of self esteem, call it what ever the hell you want, I don't care. I HATED IT. I still hate my hair although, I am thankful beyond belief to have at least some back even if I do look like the guy in Knocked Up. Every single day, I wake up and look in the mirror and get pissed. I don't want to go anywhere and I REALLY didn't want to go anywhere when I was bald. I tried the wigs, they didn't work for me. I spent my 10 months of baldness with bandana's on my head. 24/7. Short story, then I'll stop. We had sort of a family reunion/party at my house. Most people there, had not seen me since I lost my hair. Now, I never shaved my head. I refused. At this point, I had maybe 50 hairs sticking out from my bandana. EVERYFREAKINGBODY at that party was saying things that you all have mentioned; "It'll grow back" blah, blah, blah. I was so tired. And, sick. I was sick and tired of people trying to make me feel better about being bald!!! So, I decided to "hide" for a minute. I had a little sitting area outside. I was sitting there when my bro's girlfriend (who I love) came up and sat down. She said "Is that all that's left of your hair?" I said "Yes." She said "That sucks." and she cried with me. I love that girl. Kudos to you Hasling. For me, what I hated most about being bald was EVERYTHING. Hugs everybody, Traci

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 03:22PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: Hi Smiley, :) First I want to say don't wait 'til the Dr is out of the room to look at your file. You are entitled to a copy of every single piece of paper all of your doctors create about you. Every scan, every mammo, every everything, and I encourage you to get those copies so you can do your own research and get a second opinion if you want.  That is YOUR file, not theirs. Second, yes....some doctors absolutely leave out details. Recently I was with my Mom at her Ocologist office and he said something along the lines of: "some of the tumors are smaller, and some are larger...." when we got home and I finally had a chance to read the most recent path report, which I simply had to wait for a copy to be made after the Onc was finished, I discovered that she had two NEW tumors! He didn't bother telling us that. (Perhaps because he new she was near the end of her life and thought that telling her that would benefit no one, but whatever.) I hope that what you felt is nothing, but you have to be your own advocate. Get copies of everything so you can read all the results, comments, etc., with your own two eyes. (((((((hugs))))))) Traci

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 09:06AM - edited Sep 30, 2007 09:06AM by Traci-----TripNeg Hi esm, I'm copying and pasting what I posted on the other thread. I think it works for your comment too. I am brca+. My little sis who had bc 9 yrs ago got tested after my bc dx and she too is +. My older sister who had uterine and cervical cancer 2 yrs ago is negative. My other sister has yet to be tested. We all have the same mom and dad. I have 9 neices 18 or younger. So far, 3 have been tested. 2 positive, one negative. The negative one, 16 yrs old, has already had a scare with something on her ovaries. Thank God, it was not cancer. Honestly, I don't think any of this matters really. I believe cancer is a part of our make up as a human being. (A doctor (onc) told me that when I was on a plane going to see my little sis after her dx.)  Whether or not it rears it's ugly head is a crap shoot. I wish you the best of luck. Sincerely, Traci

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 01:27AM - edited Oct 8, 2007 01:27AM by Traci-----TripNeg Oz, I wish you the best of luck with your new onc.....and the results you have with him/her. We'll be thinking about you on the 15th. As far as the anti-depressents....I take xanax. When I first felt my lump I shook on the inside. I couldn't shake on the outside...work...family...friends...you gotta be strong..but, on the inside, I was losing it. The xanax really, really helped me. But, like badboob says, they do not work for everybody. I hope you find what works for you to keep your stress in check. Geeta, Good thing your not near her old onc!! After the shaking I can see a kick in the jaw! Diane, I love your post about shoes you have to tie. Really. I swear, I am going to try that. Some mornings it is so hard to keep going after that initial awakening. That is an awesome idea. And btw, I cringe everytime I see your posts about your lost films.....gawd...are they still looking for them? I mean, in my business there are tons of files too and yes, files do get lost. However, we always find them! One time, (true story) after a girl was let go, there were numerous files missing. We looked in every inch of the office. Including......are you ready......the ceiling tiles. This girl was hiding files in the ceiling tiles!!!!! Someone had seen or heard of it and sure enough.....there they were. Funny but....not funny. Good luck Oz. Please keep us posted. Night everybody. Hugs, Traci

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 12:16PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: (((((Stephanie))))) I posted this a long time ago but you're story made the memory rush back into my brain. Some days after my bi-mast, I went out to my front porch to take in some outdoor air. Two teenage boys (16ish?) were riding by on their bicycles. I waved, smiled and said hello and they turned around as if to "check me out" and when the one kid got a better look he said "Man, you are flat chested!" I was shocked. I yelled back "That's because I just had my breasts cut off thanks to cancer!!!!" You should have seen the look on that kids face. I know he was mortified. I doubt he ever makes another comment like that again in his life. I also doubt that your neighbor let that go. I'm sure she gave that young man a lecture about what he did, impulsive reaction or not, and I'm sure he feels very badly about what happened. Or, maybe he doesn't....if he doesn't, then God help him. Like you, I was crushed to tears. I cried for a long time. I'm so sorry you had to have that happen after all you have been through. Hugs, Traci

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 07:43PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: Deep sigh.............. Hi Rusty, I don't think we've met; I'm Traci. I'm so happy to meet you although, I'm sorry it's under such shitty circumstances. I'm not having a good day either but mine is nothing compared to yours. I read your post three times, and just cried a really needed cry. It hurts my heart that you are going through this at such a young age. I mean, it sucks for all of us but...you are so young. I'm so sorry. You make me think of this girl I sat across from in that cold chemo room. She was so young. She was thin and pretty with long blonde hair. She was so scared. She didn't belong in there. She looked really out of place. She looked like she belonged in college, surrounding by boys. They couldn't find a vein in her tiny arms. She started to cry. Finally, the awesome nurse (they were all great weren't they...but isn't there always one that is awesome?) came over to her chair to try. I don't know what she said to the girl but, she made her smile through her tears and she rubbed her arm gently for a few minutes to warm her up, and her blood. She found a vein with only one stick. I'll never forget that girls face. Never. When I got my last blood work done, I asked about that girl and was told that she was finished with treatment and doing o.k. I forget what the point to that story was......I guess I was just....I don't know. I'm sorry your having such a terrible time. It breaks my heart today. I wish there was something I could do. Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 02:13PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: Hey Jen, ((((hugs)))) I took Xanax when I was first diagnosed, losing my business, filing for bankruptcy, and knowing I was going to lose my home to foreclosure. It helped me immediately. Honestly, I don't know how I would have coped without it. She warned me of the addictiveness of the drug, and I headed that warning. I only took it when I could feel the anxiety coming on. And in spite of the fact that kids today are paying $20 for one pill, it didn't do anything to me except calm me down. I can't remember the dose, but I'm sure it was the smallest available. I never felt loopey or high or anything like that. It's hard to describe...it just worked. My Sister Debbi takes Zoloft. When our big brother got married recently, everybody was shedding tears of happiness for him during the ceremony. Debbi was sitting next to me and I said: "I can't believe your not crying." She said: "I want to cry, but I took my Zoloft." Our big Sister Denise is a major stressoholic. She takes everything too seriously, and is just so melodramatic. It was starting to weigh on her life/marriage. Debbi convinced her to try Zoloft, and now she's a happy camper. Really. Find one that works for you my friend, because they do work. Traci PS: I haven't taken Xanax regularly, or even often, for a couple of years now. I just needed something to get over those massives freaking hurdles, treaments, etc. Now I just pop one if I get stressed, like during football season when the Cowboys play the Eagles or Giants.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 11:08AM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: Barb, you're so cool. :) Button up tops are so helpful. (Necessary?) They've got the super soft ones now in the jammy section that I highly recommend, and if you get the ones with pockets, you can wear it inside out and put the drains in the pockets. That's a tip I got on this board that worked wonders for me. It beat the heck out of safety pinning the drains to whatever I was wearing. Another girl got button up 'moo moo's' with pockets and wore them inside out. I never got one of those, but that too is an awesome idea for the drains and all the stores like Penny's etc., have those. Like Barb, I didn't experience any real 'pain', just very stiff and tight torso. Another tip I got on here was for exercise. Stand next to a walll and crawl your hands up the wall like a spider to slowly stretch your muscles. That helped a lot too. Good luck, Ladies!!! Like Barb said, it's not near as bad as your brain would think. I was actually shocked at how little it 'hurt'. :) Traci

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 10:33PM - edited Jan 4, 2008 10:36PM by Traci-----TripNeg Hey Topaz, I'm happy to hear that you got reversed news! I wanted to address one of your original questions though. My 'lil fellow bc sis...had a bone biopsy of her t-7 and another vertabrae (sp?) and unlike LuAnne (God love you girl) it was horrible for her. If...you have to have this procedure, make them put you under. They may tell you they "need you awake" but you tell them, you do not want to feel any pain. My sister came out of there broken up and she is a strong girl. She was really crying hard about the pain she endured. She battled chemo 9 years ago when they didn't have the meds to make you not throw up. Thank God, they said it wasn't cancer in her spine. Only degeneretive (sp?) stuff. Anyway, I'm happy for your good news!!!! Hugs, Traci

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 05:24AM - edited Jun 18, 2008 05:26AM by Traci-----TripNeg Hi Janis,  Ladies, I'm not saying this to get any feedback and I definitely don't mean to offend anyone but Janis, I think this is a wonderful idea. Daily, I wish I had a child to write one for and daily, I wish my father would have left one for me when he passed. Don't know if you remember or not but, when 'ForTheMoment' aka Erin died, I went to her service and they had a letter from her to her 2 yr old daughter up on the huge screen for everyone to read. It was the most beautiful letter I had ever read. It brought me to uncontrollable tears. I just know that when her baby is old enough to read and appreciate that letter, it will always mean more to her than anything else she will ever encounter in life. It was breathtakingly heartfelt.  Having said all of that...remember what Lisa40 used to say: fists up!! Love, Traci

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 10:54PM Traci-----TripNeg wrote: lol Geeta!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! ....you are too funny! Did you make that up???? FLLorick, Don't let it bother you. Shake it off. Some people are just busy bodies. My brother has two bad knees. He has a handicap permit as well. I went with him to the grocery store one day. We had been at his house, sitting, watching football. When we got to the store, he was able to walk in with no problem. Someone also approached us. It was a much older man and boy, was he is lecture mode. My brother who is hysterical (like Geeta) started saying stuff to him in a foreign lauguage that he made up. It was so funny. Thanks for bringing back that memory and making me laugh. Anyway, the old man ended up walking away scared. lol.... And, the end to the story is...by the time we were done with the shopping, my brother practically needed a wheelchair to get to the car. Ignore people like this or, kill them with kindness.  And certaintly.....don't let them ruin your day. Hugs, Traci
